phrasetype.name: Noun
phrasetype.phrase: Collection Content ID and Collection ID
Container Type, Number, Parent, and Collection

phrasetype.name: Message

phrase.name: accountactivated
phrase.regularexpression: Researcher account activated\. If you would like to make an appointment, please log in\.

phrasetype.phrase: Researcher account activated. If you would like to make an appointment, please log in.

phrase.name: activationemailsent
phrase.regularexpression: Thank you for registering! An E-mail has been sent to ([\w@.]+) with information about how to confirm your account\.

phrasetype.phrase: Thank you for registering! An E-mail has been sent to $1 with information about how to confirm your account.

phrase.name: appointmentemailsent
phrase.regularexpression: Thank you! An e-mail has been sent with the details of your appointment\.

phrasetype.phrase: Thank you! An e-mail has been sent with the details of your appointment.

phrase.name: error_reason_beforearrivaltime
phrase.regularexpression: ([\w]+) cannot be before the arrival time\.

phrasetype.phrase: $1 cannot be before the arrival time.

phrase.name: error_reason_beforecurrenttime
phrase.regularexpression: ([\w]+) cannot be before the current time\.

phrasetype.phrase: $1 cannot be before the current time.

phrase.name: error_reason_loginforappointment
phrase.regularexpression: You must be logged in to make an appointment\.

phrasetype.phrase: You must be logged in to make an appointment.

phrase.name: error_reason_notresearcher
phrase.regularexpression: Current user is not a researcher\.

phrasetype.phrase: Current user is not a researcher.

phrase.name: error_reason_onlyresearchersmakeappointments
phrase.regularexpression: Only researchers may make an appointment\.

phrasetype.phrase: Only researchers may make an appointment.

phrase.name: error_reason_slashinidentifier
phrase.regularexpression: The CollectionIdentifier may not contain the character '\/'\.

phrasetype.phrase: The Collection Identifier may not contain the character '/'.

phrase.name: youremailsent
phrase.regularexpression: Thank you! Your e-mail has been sent\.

phrasetype.phrase: Thank you! Your e-mail has been sent.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use these two fields to record the street or postal address of the researcher.
Use these fields to record the city, state, and zip code for the researcher.
If defined, classification identifiers that are numbers will be padded with zeros to ensure the number appears with at least the minimum number of characters.
If defined, collection identifiers consisting only of numerals will be padded with zeros to ensure the numbers appear with at least the minimum number of characters.
If enabled, new researcher accounts will have their e-mail addresses verified before their account is fully activated.
This value determines the default repository. This primarly affects the output of data on the default style.
Enabling this directive will have Archon cache finding aid output in the database. This may significantly increase finding aid page generation time, after initially cached.
Enables User-defined fields in the collections manager at the content level.
Setting this option to 'yes' causes the default public interface theme to do searches over all collection content. Other themes can take advantage of this option as well.
If this option is enabled, search results will be ordered by classification. As a consequence, any collections not associated with a classification will not be searchable.
In order for the addition or update to succeed, the value entered here must be the same as the password in the field above.
Use this field to record the e-mail address of the researcher.
Use this field to record the first name of the researcher.
Use the Researcher Types Manager to develop a list of general categories describing the different kinds of researchers who use your repository, e.g. students, faculty, or members of the public.
The Collection CSV import script takes collection information from a csv (comma-separated values) file and imports it into Archon. Please see the Archon documentation for details.
The Collection Content CSV import script takes content information from a csv (comma-separated values) file and imports it into Archon. Please see the Archon documentation for details.
The EAD XML import script takes finding aids in EAD format and imports them to Archon.
The MARC Record import script takes MARC Records and imports them to the collections table.
Use this field to record the last name of the researcher.
Use this field to record or change a researcher's login password.
Check 'Yes' to indicate the researcher's account as pending. When an account is pending, the researcher cannot submit a request to checkout materials.
Use these fields to record a phone number and, optionally, a phone extension, for the researcher.
Use this field to specify what kind of researcher the person is.

Use this drop-down list to select the default repository under which the user will create and edit collections.
This applies only if more than one repository has been defined within your installation of Archon, using in the Repository Manager.
Use this field to allow or disallow users from viewing, adding, and updating collection records in Archon repositories, other than the primary one to which he/she is assigned.
The Upcoming Appointments widget displays research appointments that users have requested for the current week.

This widget lists the upcoming appointments for the current week.
Use the buttons with green arrows to indicate that the archival materials have been retrieved for the researcher's use. Use the buttons with red arrows to indicate that the archival materials have been returned to their storage location. The buttons next to the appointment entry will retrieve or return all materials for the appointment, and the buttons next to the collection title will retrieve or return all requested materials for that collection.

The Collection List Widget can be used to display a list of collections from within any administrative module configured to use it. Modules can then associate information with that chosen collection.
When placed on your home page, the widget provides a quick way to access collections for editing.

To find an existing collection record, type the collection title or ID into the 'Filter' box. Then click the title.
If your institution uses the classification manager to group collections into record groups, separate components of the ID with slashes, e.g '12/2/24' for record group '12', subgroup '12', record series '24'.
To add a new collection, click 'Add New'.

phrasetype.name: Administrative Phrase
phrasetype.phrase: Limit User to only this repository's collections
No appointments scheduled for this week.
No location entries found for collection.

phrasetype.name: Public Phrase
phrasetype.phrase: Your 'cart' currently holds the following materials. This list will be appended to your email message.
Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.
Fields marked with an asterisk (*) are required.
Searching within the finding aid for $1

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Open this section to record information about the dates and manner of acquisition, as well as the source of acquisition and custodial history.

Use this field to record information regarding anticipated additions to the collection, or information regarding additions that are already in the custody of the repository (See DACS Rule 5.4 for more information on the use of this element).

Use these fields to record, in mm/dd/yy format, the date when materials in the collection were first received. This information will be recorded in the MARC and EAD fields for acquisition information as follows: "The materials were acquired by [repository name] on [date]."

Use this field to identify the source from which the repository directly acquired the materials being described, as well as the date of acquisition, the method of acquisition, and other relevant information, if such information is not included in other Archon fields for acquisition information (See DACS Rule 5.2 for more information).
Use this field to record the source from which the repository directly acquired the materials being described (DACS rule 5.2).

Use this field to record information about the rationale for appraisal decisions, destruction actions, and disposition schedules that are relavent to understanding and use of the materials being described (See DACS Rule 6.3 for more information).

Use this field to provide information on changes of ownership or custody of the material being described, from the time it left the possession of the creator until it was acquired by the repository, that is significant for understanding its authenticity, integrity, and interpretation (See DACS Rule 5.1 for more information).
Open this section to link books records to the collection.

Use this drop-down to select a 'classification,' such as a record groups, into which you may sort materials to relate them by provenance, function, or general subject. When a classification is selected, a list of associated subclassifications (if any) will appear, so that the collections may be further sorted into subgroups.

Use this field to record a unique identifier assigned to the collection. (If the classification manger is being used by your repository, the information recorded here is used in conjunction with the classification ids selected above to constitute the unique identifier.)
Enter the date(s) associated with the materials you are describing at the current level of description.
Enter an expanded description (scope and content note) of the materials being described at this level of description.

Use the 'Component Manager' to add or edit subordinate components within a collection record, such as series, boxes, folders, or items. Use this interface to create new content. Enter deeper into the hierarchy of existing content by double-clicking the title of a piece of content. Edit existing content by single-clicking the title of a piece of content.

This drop-down box lists levels of description and container types. Use it ti choose the level and/or type of container appropriate for the level of description or container you are adding or editing.
For "physical only" containers, you will NOT be able to record any descriptive information other than Title and Dates. Please note that these title and dates are provided for convenience only, and will NOT be recorded in the EAD output. Description of materials in a physical container MUST take place by nesting content within the the container after double clicking the container in the "Content Contained by" box.

Use this field to record the sequential order of the level or container you are adding or updating. Multiple entries can be created at once by separating numbers with commas and/or hyphens (i.e. 1,3,7-16,24).
Use this field to specify how far you want to shift the Level/Container Numbers during the renumbering.
Use these buttons to choose which direction you want to shift the Level/Container Numbers during the renumbering.

Use this field to record a title for the materials being described at the current level of description. This field maps to the <unittitle> element in the EAD output, in the <dsc>, at the appropriate level.

Use this manager to transfer content within a logical or physical hierarchy. Click on the name of a piece of content below to move higher in the hierarchy or choose a piece in the current location to move deeper inside.
Use this drop-down box to specify the type of element that the user-defined field will be mapped to in Archon's EAD output.

Provide a label or column heading that will appear with the user defined field (in both the public website and the EAD output). For example, if you are mapping a user defined field to the EAD creator element, and using it to record the composer of a musical work, set the label to "Composer".
Enter the text of the user defined field. This value will be mapped into the EAD element specified with the head or label specified in the label/head field.
Open this section to link creator authority records to the collection.

After highlighting a creator name, use the right arrow to link it to the current collection. Use the left arrow to unlink the creator. CTRL-click selects multiple creators and SHIFT-click selects a range of items.

Use the upper box to filter names from the master list of creators, then double click a creator name from the filtered list (or use the arrows) to apply it to the collection. The first creator to appear in the right hand list will be identified as the primary creator of the collection.
Open this section to record descriptive information, such as a scope and content, arrangement note, or alternate extent statement for the collection.
Use this field to provide an abstract.
Use this field to record an alternate or expanded statement regarding the extent and physical nature of the materials being described. (See DACS Rule 2.5 for more information.)

Use this field to provide a short note regarding the order of the materials or to identify the aggregations of archival material, their relationships, or the sequence of documents within them. (See DACS Rule 3.2 for more information.)
Use this field to provide information about the organization or individual associated with the creation, assembly, accumulation and/or maintenance of the archival materials for the collection.
Use this field to record the name of the individual or individuals who created the biographical or historical note.

Use this field to provide a scope note, i.e. information about the overall nature of the materials and activities reflected in the collection, in order to enable users to judge its potential relevance. (See DACS Rule 3.1 for more information.)

Use the 'Collections Manager' to create new collection records and edit existing ones. Collections may be grouped hierarchically according to classifications established in the Classification Manager. Click the Content Manager button to create a finding aid or inventory, or to describe the subordinate components of a collection, such as the series, boxes, folders, or items.
Changing this radio button to 'no' will suppress the public view of the collection's summary record and finding aid.

Use this field to record the units of measure which most accurately represents the overall extent of the collection. Additional information about the collection's extent can be provided in the Alternate Extent Statement Field in the collection description area (See DACS Rule 2.5 for more information).
Open this section to record information regarding the descriptive record itself, the processing of the collection, or the author of the finding aid.
Use this drop-down list to record the set of descriptive rules under which the collection description was developed (e.g. DACS or APPM).
Use this drop-down list to select the language in which the collection description was written.

Use this field to record information regarding the processing of the collection that would aid potential users in understanding or using the materials (e.g., information regarding the use of a sampling technique, heavy weeding, or reformatting of originals).
Use this field to record the year in which the collection description was written.
Use this field to record any relevent information concerning the publication of the finding aid or other descriptive information regarding the collection.
Use this field to record information about revisions to the finding aid or descriptive record.
Use this field to record the name or names of the individuals responsible for preparing this descriptive record.
Open this section to record the genres or forms of material included in the collection.

After highlighting a genre/form of material, use the right arrow to link it to the current collection. Use the left arrow to unlink it. CTRL-click to select multiple genres and SHIFT-click to select a range of genres.
Use the upper box to filter terms from the master list of genres, then double click a genre term from the filtered list (or use the arrows) to apply it to the collection.

To find an existing collection record, type the collection title or ID into the 'Filter' box. Then click the title.
If your institution uses the classification manager to group collections into record groups, separate components of the ID with slashes, e.g '12/2/24' for record group '12', subgroup '12', record series '24'.
To add a new collection, click 'New'.

Use this field to record the date(s) that pertain to the creation, assembly, or accumulation of the materials being described. As necessary, use a single date, span of dates, or comma separated list of dates and/or date spans. (See DACS Rule 2.4 for more information.)
Open this section if you to define the language or languages used in the materials in the collection.

After highlighting a language, use the right arrow to link it to the current collection. Use the left arrow to unlink it. CTRL-click selects multiple languages and SHIFT-click selects a range of items.
Use the upper box to filter the master list of languages, then double click a language in the filtered list (or use the arrows) to apply it to the collection.
Open this area to record the permanent locations where boxes or other containers are stored.
Use this field to record the container number(s) that are stored at the specified location.
Use these fields to record information regarding the extent of the boxes or other containers stored in the specified location.
Use this pull-down list to select the master location (e.g. room or building) where the specified materials are stored. Additional rooms or buildings can be defined in the "Location Manager."
Use this field to record the number (or other identifier) of the shelving range where the specified materials are stored.
Use this field to record the specific section (of a range) in which the materials are stored.
Use this field to record the specific shelf (at a specified section) on which the materials are stored.

Use this field to record the basic 'type' of materials being described (e.g. official records, personal papers, or publications). Additional types can be added by editing the table 'tblCol_MaterialTypes' in the database on the database server where Archon is installed.)

Use this field to record a single year or the first and last year covered by the materials in the collection. Normally this field will be automatically completed when you enter the inclusive dates. The information in this field is required for MARC output of the collection record.
Open this section to record descriptive information relating to the collection that cannot be accommodated in other fields.
Use this field to record information that cannot be accommodated in any of the defined elements of description (See DACS Rule 7.1 for more information).

Use this field to record a URL related to the collection. Use must be defined by local practice; at UIUC it is used to link to PDF finding aids for inventories not yet imported to the Archon system. The URL should be an absolute URL.

Use this field to indicate the dates pertaining to the majority of the documents in the collection being described, when those differ significantly from the inclusive dates. In other words, this field is used to provide 'predominant' or 'bulk' dates. ( There is no need to record the word 'predominant' or 'bulk', as it will automatically be added to the descriptive output.)
Use this field to select a creator record to associate as the primary creator for the records/collections.
Open this section to record information about related or separated materials.
Use this field to record information describing the existence, location, and availability of originals or copies of the materials being described (See DACS Rules 6.1 and 6.2.)
Use this field to record a URL relating to originals or copies of the materials being described. The URL should be an absolute URL.
Use this field to record the preferred citation which users should utilize when referencing the collection in published or unpublished works.

Use this field to record information regarding the existence and location of archival materials that are closely related to the materials being described by provenance, sphere of activity, or subject matter, either in the same repository, in other repositories, or elsewhere. (See DACS Rule 6.3 for more information.)
Use this field to record the URL of a website referencing materials related to the collection being described. The URL should be an absolute URL.
Use this field to identify any publication that are about or based on the use, study, or analysis of the materials being described. (See DACS element 6.4 for more information.)

Use this field to record information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials but that have been physically separated or removed from the collection for various reasons, including the dispersal of special formats to more appropriate custodial units, the destruction of duplicate or nonessential material, and the deliberate or unintentional scattering of materials among different repositories.
Use this drop-down list to select the repository that manages the collection being added or updated.
Open this section to record information on access, use or other restrictions related to the collection.

Use this field to record information about access restrictions, such as those imposed by the donor, by the repository, or by statutory/regulatory requirements. (See DACS Rule 4.1 for more information.)

Use this field to provide information about access restrictions due to any limiting physical characteristic (such as the use of remote storage locations) that might limit, restrict, delay, or otherwise affect access to the materials being described. (See DACS Rule 4.2 for more information).

Use this field to provide information about access restrictions due to any technological requirements (e.g. the need to use special playback equipment or computer programs) that might restrict or otherwise affect access to the materials being described. (See DACS Rule 4.3 for more information.)
Use this field to identify any restrictions on reproduction due to copyright or other reasons. (See DACS Rule 4.4 for more information).
Use this field to record a title which is used for sorting purposes when displaying results to users This is useful with collection titles that begin with "a," "an," or "the".
Open this section to link an existing subject authority record to the collection.

After highlighting a subject, use the right arrow to link it to the current collection. Use the left arrow to unlink the subject. CTRL-click to select multiple subjects and SHIFT-click to select a range of items.
Use the upper box to filter subject terms from the master list of subjects, then double click a term in the filtered list (or use the arrows) to apply it to the collection.

This drop-down box lists 'templates' that will determine the page layout of collections information in the public interface. If the default template does not provide an acceptable output, select another template. (Additional templates can be designed and added to the templates folder on the webserver where Archon is installed.)

Use this field to record a word or phrase by which the material being described is known or can be identified. A title may be formal or supplied. Do not include the dates. This is a required field, and maps to filed 100 or 110 in the MARC output. (See DACS Rule 2.3 for complete rules on forming titles.)

phrasetype.name: Administrative Phrase
phrasetype.phrase:
This will delete the selected collection AND ALL content contained within.
Are you sure?

This will delete this content, AND all content contained by this content.
Are you sure you want to do this?
Please select a new container to contain the content
WARNING: No Primary Creator has been applied for this collection.
WARNING: No Primary Creator has been applied for this collection.
No classification information has been entered into the Classification Manager.
Cancel Changes and Return to Collection List

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: This field shows list of collections available at this location.
This field shows total number of collections at this location.
Use this field to describe the types of materials that are stored in this location.
This field shows physical size or extent for the collection.
The Location Manager is used to define a repository's storage locations, i.e. the rooms and/or buildings where archival materials are permanently housed.
Open this section to store total number of collections, collection names, and physical size or extent of a collection at a location.
Use this field to record the name of a discrete storage location (e.g. a building name and room number) that differentiates this storage location from others used by your repository.
Select the repositories to which this location belongs.
Check this checkbox if you want to limit access to this location only to the selected repositories.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Optionally, use this section to define children (such as subgroups) of the [b]current [/b]classification you are editing.  Children may be defined to any depth necessary, but in practical terms three levels is usually the most that will be intelligible to users.  Defining additional layers can affect system performance.
Double click to select an available item within the collection classification window.
Use this field to record the identifier assigned to the classification (e.g. record group or subgroup) being established or updated.
This field shows a list of creators. Choose the correct creator for the classification being added or updated.
Type in this field to filter the list of creators, then double click a creator name to link it to the classification as an authority record.
Use this field to select a creator name and link it to the classification as an authority record.
Use this field to provide additional information about the classification (or the function or creator associated with the classification).

Use of the 'Classification Manager' is optional. It may be used to develop a hierarchy, such as record groups and subgroups. (Once a hierarchy is established, the Collection Manager is used to nest collections in the hierarchy.) Use this interface to add new classifications, nest sub-classifications within an existing level (by double clicking a classification title), or edit an existing title (by single clicking the title).
Use this field to record or edit the title (e.g. the name of the record group or subgroup) of the classification level being added or updated.

Use this manager to move classifications into different positions within the hierarchy. To do this, use the menu at the bottom to choose a new parent from within the current location in the hierarchy. You can also change to a location higher up by clicking on one of the classifications listed.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase:
The Material Types Manager is used to define classes of material held by a repository (e.g. Records, Personal Papers, Family Papers, Publications, etc).
NOTE: Genres or forms of material are specified in the Subject/Genre Manager, NOT the Material Types Manager.
Use this field to add or update terms used to distinguish classes of materials held by your repository, (e.g. personal papers vs. official records/archives).

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this field to record the value that will be written into the level attribute of the EAD output whenever the selected level is used in the Content Manager. Consult the EAD Tag Library's documentation for the <c> element for a list of the valid attribute values. This field should be left blank for levels that represent solely a physical container, such as boxes.

Checking 'yes' indicates that the numbering for the named level will not restart at one when the level is used within a new parent level in the Content Manger. E.g., if 'yes' is checked for the 'box' level/container, and you move to a new series, the default number will not restart at one the next time you record a box in the new series.
Checking 'no' indicates that numbering for the named level will restart at 1 when the level is used within a new parent level in the Content Manager. For example, if 'yes' is checked for the 'item' level, and you move to a new folder, the next number assigned to an item will be 1.
Use the Level/Container Manager to define, edit or delete the levels of description and types of physical containers in which materials may be nested using the Content Manager.

Check 'Intellectual Level' if the name of the level/container represents ONLY an intellectual level of description, such as 'record group,' 'series,' or 'item.' Whenever the named level is selected in the Content Manager, the value recorded in the 'EAD level' field will be output as the level attribute of the <c0x> element. Check both "Intellectual Level" and "Physical Container" if the level/container is intended to represent both a physical container and an intellectual level of description. </c0x>Whenever the named level is selected in the Content Manger, the value of the EAD level will be written to the level attribute of the <c0x> level, and a <container> element will be recorded with the container number supplied by the administrative user, at the component (<c0x> level where it is recorded, and all levels nested within it).</c0x></container></c0x>

Use this field to define or edit the name associated with an intellectual level of description and/or container type. The levels/containers named here will be available for use in the Content Manager.

Check 'Physical Container' if the name of the level/container represents ONLY a physical container in which archival materials are stored. Whenever the named level is used in the Content Manger, the container number recorded in the Content Manger will be applied to all content nested underneath it. For example, if the level name is box and the level/container number is set to 10, a <container type="box">10</container> element will be encoded in the EAD output for content nested in the box 10. The administrative user will be able to provide ONLY a title and dates the box itself and the title and dates will NOT be recorded in the EAD output. All information about materials in box 10 MUST be recorded in subsequent levels.

Check 'No' if the Container type is NOT the primary one which maps to the value of the 'EAD Level" defined above. For example, if the 'Container Type' is set to 'Tube' and 'EAD level' is set to 'file,' check no.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: The Researcher Account Manager is used to look up or provide details about researchers using Archon to locate materials.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use the Researcher Types Manager to develop a list of general categories describing the different kinds of researchers who use your repository, e.g. students, faculty, or members of the public.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this field to record a unit of physical size or extent.

Use the Extent Units Manger to define units which describe the physical size or extent of a collection. The units defined here will be available for selection in a drop-down box in the Collection Manager.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this section to add and edit children (e.g. boxes, files or items) under the current content record that you are editing.  You may select an existing child to edit by selecting it from the list and waiting for the record to load.
Use double click to select a available item within the collection content.
Enter the date(s) associated with the materials you are describing at the current level of description.
Enter an expanded description (scope and content note) of the materials being described at this level of description.

Use the 'Content Manager' to add or edit subordinate components within a collection record, such as series, boxes, folders, or items..Use this interface to create new content. Enter deeper into the hierarchy of existing content by double-clicking the title of a piece of content. Edit existing content by double-clicking the title of a piece of content.

This drop-down box lists levels of description and container types. Use it to choose the level and/or type of container appropriate for the level of description or container you are adding or editing.
For "physical only" containers, you will NOT be able to record any descriptive information other than Title and Dates. Please note that these title and dates are provided for convenience only, and will NOT be recorded in the EAD output. Description of materials in a physical container MUST take place by nesting content within the the container after double clicking the container in the "Content Contained by" box.

Use this field to record the sequential order of the level or container you are adding or updating. Alphanumeric labels could be used for labels (i.e A1). Multiple entries can be created at once by separating numbers with commas and/or hyphens (i.e. 1,3,7-16,24).
This field displays the parent collection of this content.

Use this field to record a title for the materials being described at the current level of description. This field maps to the <unittitle label="Private" audience="internal"> element in the EAD output, in the <did>, at the appropriate level.
Use this field to select a collection by typing text into the text box; a list of available collections will appear as you type.
Use this field to change the order of available items for the same collection content. Item assigned the lowest number will appear first in the list.

Use this field to record a title for the materials being described at the current level of description. This field maps to the <unittitle> element in the EAD output, in the <did>, at the appropriate level.

Provide a label or column heading that will appear with the user defined field (in both the public website and the EAD output). For example, if you are mapping a user defined field to the EAD creator element, and using it to record the composer of a musical work, set the label to "Composer".
Use this drop-down box to specify the type of element that the user-defined field will be mapped to in Archon's EAD output.
Enter the text of the user defined field. This value will be mapped into the EAD element specified with the head or label specified in the label/head field.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Open this section if you to define the collection or collections used for the books.
Use this field to record copy number of the book.
Open this section to link creator authority records to the collection.
Use this field to record descriptive information about the book.
Use this field to record edition number of the book.
Open this section to record the genres or forms of material included in the book.
Use the Book Manager to describe new books in the collection that have not been processed and cataloged.
Use this field to record an identifier of the book.
Open this section if you to define the language or languages used in the books in the collection.
Use this field to record addition note about the book.
Use this field to record total number of pages in the book.
Use this field to record publication place of the book.
Use this field to select a creator record to associate as the primary creator for the records/collections.
Use this field to record publication date of the book.
Use this field to record publisher name of the book.
Use this field to record series of the book.
Open this section to link an existing subject authority record to the book.
Use this field to give a title to the book.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this field to provide a name describing the purpose for a researcher's visit.

The Appointment Purposes Manager is used to list the different purposes for which research appointment may be scheduled. The values entered here will be available to archival users when the register an appointment through the public website.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this field to select the purpose that most closely describes the researcher's use of the archival materials.
Use this field to select the the phrase which most closely describes the purpose for which the researcher is using the archival materials.
Use this field to record any comments about the research appointment.
Use this field to specify the researcher's expected arrival time.
Use this field to specify the researcher's expected departure time.

The Appointments Manager is used to schedule and manage information regarding researcher appointments.
Use the buttons with green arrows to indicate that the archival materials have been retrieved for the researcher's use. Use the buttons with red arrows to indicate that the archival materials have been returned to their storage location.
The buttons next to the appointment entry will retrieve or return all materials for the appointment, and the buttons next to the collection title will retrieve or return all requested materials for that collection.
Use this field to record any comments submitted by theresearcher who scheduled the appointment.
Use this menu to select the researcher for the appointment.
This field shows the time of the appointment request was submitted.
Use this field to specify the topic or subject being studied during the research appointment.

phrasetype.name: Description
phrasetype.phrase: Use this field to record the named values (e.g. "student" or "public") that may associated with researchers. The values recorded here will appear in a drop down list in the registration page and Public Users manager.
